will enter the city.

original: manaāpaśca na kadācidyakṣatvaṃ na rākṣasatvaṃ na bhūtatvaṃ na piśācatvaṃ na pūtanatvaṃ na kaṭapūtanatvaṃ na manuṣyadāridryaṃ pratyanubhaviṣyati

analyzed: sa ca rāga dveṣa moha māna darpa vigataḥ bhaviṣyati

translated: For any human harm, animal harm, cow harm, all calamities, epidemics, troubles, and invasions by foreign armies,🔽 if one recites this Aparajita, the great knowledge queen, the white parasol of the Tathagata's uṣṇīṣa, all of them will be pacified.🔽 If one is afflicted by a disease of the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, or mind,
